title: U.S. Imports Grew in 2025, as Trump’s Tariffs Reshuffled Global Trade
partialText: Data released Thursday by the Census Bureau showed the overall trade deficit with the world narrowed, the result of an expanding trade surplus in services. The trade deficit in goods was the highest on record.

title: Jittery Markets Seek an Iran ‘Off-Ramp’
partialText: Oil prices spiked and stocks fell as tensions between Washington and Tehran unnerved investors.

title: Walmart Expects Growth Streak to Continue as New Chief Takes Over
partialText: Shoppers are turning to Walmart to stretch their dollars, but an uncertain economy and trade tensions will test the retailer’s new executive team.

title: Uber Moves to Enact Stricter Background Checks for Drivers
partialText: The New York Times revealed in December that the ride-hailing giant approved drivers with many types of criminal convictions, including violent felonies.

title: Ring’s Founder Knows You Hated That Super Bowl Ad
partialText: Since the commercial aired, Jamie Siminoff has been trying to quell an outcry over privacy concerns with his doorbell cameras.

title: Trump Mulls a North American Trade Pact Without Canada
partialText: U.S. officials are threatening major changes to a trade agreement with Mexico and Canada that could upend the way business is done and leave Canada on the outs.

title: Money Talks as India Searches for Its Place in Global A.I.
partialText: Narendra Modi, the prime minister, convened foreign leaders, the richest Silicon Valley companies and thousands of Indian entrepreneurs for a week of deal making.

title: Stock Slide and Slow Sales: What’s Happening in China’s E.V. Market?
partialText: Investors are selling shares of Chinese E.V. companies, concerned that intensifying competition and shorter production cycles mean the years of easy growth are over.

title: Defense Department and Anthropic Square Off in Dispute Over A.I. Safety
partialText: How artificial intelligence will be used in future battlefields is an issue that has turned increasingly political and may put Anthropic in a bind.

title: Donald J. Trump International Airport? The President’s Company Trademarked It.
partialText: The Trump organization said the move was necessary to protect the brand as Florida prepares to rename an airport after the president.

title: Workplace Inspections by OSHA Dropped Over a Six-Month Period of 2025
partialText: Labor advocates worry that the Trump administration is relaxing oversight of companies and increasing the potential for serious injuries and deaths.

title: Edison Will Reduce Executive Bonuses as a Result of the Eaton Fire
partialText: Southern California Edison had said its electrical equipment most likely caused the blaze, which destroyed much of Altadena, a Los Angeles suburb.

title: Etsy Sells Depop, a Secondhand Clothing App Popular With Gen Z, to eBay
partialText: The $1.2 billion deal comes as eBay looks to expand its appeal among younger users.

title: Fed Minutes Show No Rush to Restart Rate Cuts
partialText: Barring a rapid deterioration in the labor market or a significant cooling of inflation, the Federal Reserve appears poised for an extended hold.

title: What Do A.I. Chatbots Discuss Among Themselves? We Sent One to Find Out.
partialText: We interviewed our bot about what it learned on Moltbook, the A.I.-only social network.

title: The New York Times Wins 3 Polk Awards
partialText: The Times was honored for its coverage of President Trump, the abuse of housekeepers and nannies in Saudi Arabia and brutality in New York prisons.

title: Kentucky Derby Operator Accused of Regulatory ‘Freeloading’
partialText: The Horseracing Integrity and Safety Authority filed a complaint saying Churchill Downs Inc. is not paying its fair share to support inspections and testing.

title: Elon Musk’s xAI Gets $3 Billion Investment From Saudi-Backed A.I. Firm
partialText: Humain, which was created by Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman last year, said it made the investment just before xAI was acquired by SpaceX, Mr. Musk’s rocket company.

title: F.D.A. Reverses Decision and Agrees to Review Moderna’s Flu Vaccine
partialText: Moderna held further discussions with regulators and announced that the agency would accept the company’s application for approval of its flu vaccine that uses mRNA technology.

title: How Crypto’s Lobbying Muscle May Save the Clarity Act
partialText: A market rout may have decimated the crypto industry. But its machine in Washington may power proposed regulation past concerned Democrats.

title: Uber Taking Steps to Expand Number of EV Chargers Near Its Drivers
partialText: The company said it would encourage companies that operated chargers to install them in neighborhoods where its drivers lived and work.

title: The Sleepy Market for Japanese Government Bonds Is Now a ‘Battlefield’
partialText: Trading of Japanese government bonds, long considered moribund, is roaring back to life as fears of the country’s debt have sent yields surging.

title: Boneless Wings Are Still Wings, Judge Rules
partialText: A Chicago man filed a lawsuit in 2023 against Buffalo Wild Wings, arguing that it had engaged in false advertising of its boneless wings. A judge said the claim “has no meat on its bones.”

title: Trump Hails Japan’s First Batch of U.S. Investments
partialText: The deals, totaling $36 billion, were the first step in a $550 billion investment pledge aimed at securing tariff relief and sustaining U.S. relations.

title: Goldman Sachs to Drop D.E.I. Criteria for Board Members
partialText: The move would be the Wall Street firm’s latest retreat from diversity mandates that its chief executive, David Solomon, had once made a priority.

title: Are you a medical provider who has worked in an ICE detention facility? We want to hear from you.
partialText: We want to get a better picture of what medical care for immigrants in detention is like.

title: White House Shrugs Off Lutnick’s Epstein Ties
partialText: Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick has acknowledged traveling to Jeffrey Epstein’s island and meeting him on another occasion.

title: From 2001: Rose Freedman, Last Survivor of Triangle Fire, Dies at 107
partialText: She escaped the Triangle Shirtwaist fire of 1911, in which 146 of her co-workers perished, and dedicated the rest of her life to worker safety.

title: Bayer Agrees to Pay $7.25 Billion to Settle Roundup Lawsuits
partialText: The agreement, which still faces legal hurdles, would cover current and future claims that the weedkiller caused non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma.

title: Colbert Slams Trump Administration After CBS Pulls Talarico Interview
partialText: Stephen Colbert said he had to drop an interview with James Talarico from his Monday broadcast because of new F.C.C. guidance that targeted political interviews on late-night shows.

title: GQ Names Adam Baidawi as Its Top Editor
partialText: Mr. Baidawi, 35, replaces the magazine’s longtime editor Will Welch. He says he wants the magazine to be a “North Star of masculinity.”

title: Paramount’s New Chance to Win Over Warner Bros. Discovery
partialText: The takeover battle took a new turn on Tuesday as Warner Bros. Discovery reopened talks with its rebuffed suitor. But big questions still remain.

title: Warner Bros. Discovery Restarts Deal Talks With Paramount
partialText: Paramount’s takeover bid was rejected in favor of Netflix, which wanted only the streaming and studio businesses. Paramount said it would pay more if negotiations were reopened.

title: Trump Sought Vast Budget Cuts. Congress Granted Few.
partialText: In a series of deals over the past three months, lawmakers rejected some of the president’s most aggressive attempts to whittle down the government.

title: With Niche Tech World References, Vibe Hopes Its Billboards Reach Start-Up Insiders
partialText: Billboards that wouldn’t make sense to people outside the tech industry have become common in the Bay Area. One company took the microtargeting game to another level.

title: Anderson Cooper Is Leaving ’60 Minutes’
partialText: Mr. Cooper said in a statement that he was leaving as a correspondent for the show to focus on his CNN program and spend more time with his children.

title: Vaccine Makers Curtail Research and Cut Jobs
partialText: Federal policies under Robert F. Kennedy Jr. that are hostile to vaccines have “sent a chill through the entire industry,” one scientist said.

title: Should Drug Companies Be Advertising to Consumers?
partialText: Aging means “becoming a target” of the industry, one expert said. After decades of debate, politicians of all stripes are proposing bans.

title: How the H-1B Visa Debate Is Driving a Wave of Racism Against South Asians
partialText: A dispute over the impact of H-1B visas on U.S. workers has been overshadowed by racist rhetoric, with troubling echoes of the great replacement conspiracy theory.

title: The Quiet Architect of Trump’s Global Trade War
partialText: Jamieson Greer, a low-key lawyer from a working-class background, is rewriting the rules of the global economy at the president’s behest.

title: How a Trump Tax Break Rescued Horse Racing
partialText: Owners spent nearly $1.5 billion last year on racehorses, a big increase over 2024. A new tax provision allows them to immediately deduct the full cost of the purchase.

title: Diplomatic Feud With China Weighs on Japan’s Economy
partialText: A standoff over the security of Taiwan has led to a steep decline in the number of Chinese visitors to Japan, which is heavily dependent on the tourists.

title: Warner Bros. Is Said to Consider Reopening Talks With Paramount
partialText: Warner Bros. Discovery had agreed to sell itself to Netflix, but its contract allows it to pursue offers that may lead to a superior deal.

title: Trump Administration Ends Credit for Start-Stop Feature in Cars
partialText: Manufacturers will no longer get a credit toward vehicle emissions standards by installing engines that automatically stop at red lights.

title: Like Trump, U.S. Embassies Are Raising Cash for Lavish July Fourth Parties
partialText: Some of Washington’s diplomatic outposts in Asia are raising millions for events to mark the 250th independence anniversary. One ambassador offered to sing and dance.

title: ‘Wuthering Heights’ Gallops Toward $82 Million in Global Ticket Sales
partialText: Warner Bros. spent an estimated $80 million on the R-rated romance, directed by Emerald Fennell, not including hefty marketing costs.

title: Will 2026 Be the Year of the ‘Soonicorn’?
partialText: As venture capital funding pours into start-ups large and small, more firms are pitching themselves as the next big thing.

title: What C.E.O.s Are Worried About
partialText: Fractured politics, disruptive technologies and a distrust in institutions are making it harder to focus on the traditional tasks of growing sales and profits.

title: Ring Ends Deal to Link Neighborhood Cameras After Backlash to Super Bowl Ad
partialText: A commercial about a lost dog being reunited with his family ignited concerns that a “Search Party” feature posed privacy risks. Ring parted ways with the tech company Flock Safety.
